did.unittitle: William W. Cadbury letters and watercolors

bioghist.p: William W. Cadbury (1877-1959) was a physician, Quaker missionary and botanist who collected and studied orchids and ferns. After interning at the Pennsylvania Hospital, he went, in 1909, to China as a missionary and took as position as Instructor in Materia Medica and Therapeutics at the University Medical School in Canton. He taught at the Hackett Medical College for Women, also in Canton. Later he became chief of internal medicine at Canton Hospital and served as physician to Canton Christian College. He left China in 1949, returning, via New Zealand, to New Jersey, where he spent the remainder of his days.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of correspondence of William W. Cadbury and a series of paintings of Chinese orchids. The correspondence consists of letters to Cadbury and carbon copies of letters from him. Correspondents include colleagues in the United States, China, Japan, and New Zealand. Many of the letters discuss the identification of fern specimens. Some of the letters, written while Cadbury lived in China, touch upon the political climate in China. The collection also includes nine watercolor paintings of Chinese orchids signed "Gomez," commissioned by William Cadbury.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
